) If the Supreme Court denies a petition for writ of certiorari, the taxpayer has days within which to petition for a rehearing on the denial. The case should be closed until this
-day period has expired. See CCDM
, Finality of Tax Court Decisions and Mandamus, for the finality of a Tax Court decision this situation. (
) During this
-day period, the attorney should have the files prepared for closing. Immediately upon the expiration of the

-day period, if a petition for rehearing is not filed, or if filed, is denied by the Supreme Court, the Chief Counsel attorney should take the appropriate closing action, upon whether the case has been remanded or involves a bonded taxpayer appeal. Remember that in bonded appeal cases involving tax deficiencies, sessment has not occurred and the period of limitations on assessment to run again when the decision becomes final. See section

) The Associate Chief Counsel attorney should informally check with the ment of Justice as to whether a petition for rehearing was filed and, if not, close the case immediately upon the expiration of the
-day period. (

) Adverse opinions of the court of appeals are transmitted by letter from the Appellate Section, Tax Division, Department of Justice. These are picked up Petition daily, logged in, and forwarded to the appropriate Associate’s office by the Technical Services Support Branch of the Office of the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A). (

) When the opinion of the court of appeals is adverse to the Government, the Government must decide whether or not to file a petition for writ of certiorari. The Office of Chief Counsel will make a recommendation to the Department Justice in the form of a letter to the Assistant Attorney General, Tax Division. (

) The Appellate Section of the Tax Division will review the Chief Counsel’s rec- ommendation and will prepare its own recommendation to the Assistant Attorney General (Tax Division). If the recommendations are in agreement, Appellate Section drafts a memorandum for the Assistant Attorney General the Solicitor General. (

) The Appellate Section’s recommendation may conflict with the Chief recommendation. In such a case, the Appellate Section will send Chief Counsel copies of its draft recommendation at the same time or shortly the recommendation is forwarded to the Assistant Attorney General. Time circumstances permitting, the Assistant Attorney General will withhold final action on the Tax Division’s draft recommendation in order to reconcile the ferences. A conference may be held to discuss the recommendations. (

) The Solicitor General will make the final determination as to whether to file a petition for writ of certiorari. The office of the General Counsel of the Depart- ment of the Treasury should be invited to any meeting with the office of the Solicitor General regarding any recommendation in favor of or in opposition a petition for writ of certiorari. If the Solicitor General determines that a writ certiorari should be filed, the Department of Justice will file the petition with Supreme Court. Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.

) If the adverse appellate court opinion reverses or modifies a Tax Court decision, the attorney should consult CCDM

, Cases Remanded to - the Tax Court/Recomputations, for cases remanded to the Tax Court. For example, if the Tax Court’s decision was favorable to the Government and taxpayer prevailed on appeal in the court of appeals, the case will usually be remanded to the Tax Court for entry of a new decision in accord with the mandate of the court of appeals. Any action on remand, however, must await the expiration of the certiorari period or, if certiorari is petitioned and granted, the conclusion of proceedings in the Supreme Court. Nevertheless, Area Counsel should be advised of the remand by the Associate Chief Counsel attorney. (

) As in the case of taxpayer petitions, the attorney should obtain all documents and files required to make an informed decision regarding certiorari, including the recommendation of the Appellate Section, if available. (

Copies of the letter will also be forwarded to any of the Associates or Division Counsel who were involved in developing the letter.

) When attorneys do not recommend certiorari, they should exercise common sense in deciding the scope and content of the letter. a. When the issues lost are not primarily factual, the letter should discuss adverse holding in relation to the Service positions sufficiently to provide basis for informed judgment. If the issues are primarily factual, an extensive discussion generally is not required. b. If it is clear that certiorari is not appropriate, no information memorandum is prepared and no formal coordination is required. c. Attorneys should exercise caution so as not to make statements that adversely affect future recommendations in similar cases or might prema- turely commit the Service on controversial or unresolved positions. d. Generally, attorneys should avoid phrases such as “no administrative im- portance.” Instead, use phrases such as “in the absence of a conflict, the issue currently lacks sufficient administrative importance to warrant a petition for writ of certiorari.” e. A recommendation not to apply for writ of certiorari does not, itself, indicate an acceptance of the court of appeal’s opinion. (

) When the Associate Chief Counsel attorney and branch reviewer recommend against certiorari or the Associate Chief Counsel decides against certiorari, an action memorandum is not prepared and the recommendation does not have to be formally reported to the Chief Counsel.
